msIdentifier.repository: Topkapı Palace Museum (Topkapı Sarayı Müzesi) , Istanbul

summary.p: 52 fol.; Writing surface: parchment; Shelfmark: E. H. 30; Qurʾānic Text: Q 69:35-77:50; 5 lines per page; Dimensions: 225 x 150mm; Script style: kūfī D.I; Estimated date of production: 750-900.

This entry is based on the catalogue of Fehmi E. Karatay (1888-1968), as well as the information on a sister fragment by François Déroche (see below). Currently we do not have access to the images. With exceptions, the catalogue does not contain precise information on the distribution of the text throughout the pages. For this reason, only fol. 1 is given.

Karatay (1962) describes the manuscripts as follows, p. 19: "53 E. H. 30. Kur’an’dan bir bölüm. Parşömen. 150mm boy ve 225mm eninde 52 yaprak. Sahifede tahminen III. (IX) asır kûfisiyle 160mm uzunl.[uğunda] 5 satır. Son iki yaprağında karşılıklı hendesi ve müşebbek yıldızlı güzel levhalar vardır. Son üç yaprağının kenarları kâğıtla tamir edilmiştir. Sure başları Arap üslûbunda salbekli güzel tezyinatla müzehheptir. Miklepli koyu kahverengi deri üzerine yuvarlak şemseli tahminen VIII. asır Arap cildi. Bu cilt el-Ḥāḳḳa (69) suresinin 35. ayetinden bed’ile el-Mürsalat (77) suresinin sonunda biter. Y. 49 ve 50 arası eksik olduğundan sonradan nesihle tamamlanmıştır."

This can be translated as follows: "53 E. H. 30. A part of the Qurʾān. Parchment. 52 leaves of 150 mm height and 225 mm width. The text area written in Kufic script of 3rd (9th) century [contains] 5 lines measuring 160 mm. On two last opposite leaves, there are illuminated geometric interlaced plates with müşebbek yıldız. The edges pf three last leaf have been repaired with paper. Sūra beginnings are decorated with Arabic-style salbek pattern. Probably 8th century binding on dark brown leather with flap (miklep) and mandorla (şemse). The fragment begins with Q 69:35 (Sūra al- Ḥāḳḳa) and continues until the end of Q 77 (Sūra al-Mursalāt). Since the [leaves] between [Leaf] L. 49 and 50 were missing, it was later completed with naskh."

François Déroche mentions with regard to fragment KFQ 64 of the Khalili Collection (London) that the Istanbul manuscript E. H. 30 originally comes from the same codex (Déroche 1992: p. 70). At this point, three more fragments from that same codex are known: In addition to E. H. 30 and KFQ 64, it also includes the fragments 1930.456 (Harvard Art Museums Cambridge), 63.41 (Sidney and Lois Eskenazi Museum of Art, Bloomington) and 10950 (Central Library of the University of Tehran).
